isaInvestigation.title: Investigation
isaInvestigation.description: Created using the MetaboLights Online Editor (MOE)

studies.title: Integrated microbiome-metabolome-genome axis data of Laiwu and Lulai pigs
studies.description: Excessive fat deposition can trigger metabolic diseases, and it is crucial to identify factors that can break the link between fat deposition and metabolic diseases. Healthy obese Laiwu pigs (LW) are high in fat content but resistant to metabolic diseases. In this study, we compared the fecal microbiome, fecal and blood metabolome, and genome of LW and Lulai pigs (LU) to identify factors that can block the link between fat deposition and metabolic diseases. Our results show significant differences in Spirochetes and Treponema, which are involved in carbohydrate metabolism, between LW and LU. The fecal and blood metabolome composition was similar, and some anti-metabolic disease components of blood metabolites were different between the two breeds of pigs. The predicted differential RNA is mainly enriched in lipid metabolism and glucose metabolism, which is consistent with the functions of differential microbiota and metabolites. The down-regulated gene RGP1 is strongly negatively correlated with Treponema. Our omics data would provide valuable resources for further scientific research on healthy obesity in both human and porcine.

publications.title: Integrated microbiome-metabolome-genome axis data of Laiwu and Lulai pigs
publications.authorList: Lai Xueshuang, Zhang Zhenyang, Zhang Zhe, Liu Shengqiang, Bai Chunyan, Chen Zitao, Qadri Qamar Raza, Fang Yifei, Wang Zhen, Pan Yuchun, Wang Qishan

protocols.name: Sample collection
protocols.description: Laiwu (LW) and Lulai (Laiwu x Yorkshire, LL) were provided by Jing Qi Shen Pig Farm, Jilin Province, China. Our targets, 8 LW and 8 LL were raised in similar living environments, diet and hygiene conditions for about 2 yr. No antibiotics and probiotics have been used before sample collection. Clean disposable sterile gloves were worn and pig feces caught before touching the ground to ensure samples were not contaminated and immediately stored in a small capsule (3 to 7cm) sample collection tube prefilled with a bacterial DNA protective agent. 2 tubes of feces were collected for each pig: 1 for metagenomic analysis and the other for metabolomic analysis. The target pigs were refrained from taking food for 14 h before the blood samples were collected. 5 ml of blood was collected from the jugular vein using a syringe, then transferred into a blood collection tube containing coagulant, which were inverted 5x to mix the blood and the coagulant reagent uniformly. The blood mixture was placed at room temperature for complete coagulation. 2 tubes of blood were collected for each pig: 1 for genomic analysis and the other for metabolomic analysis. All samples were transported with dry ice to the laboratory for further processing.

protocols.name: Extraction
protocols.description:
Quality control (QC) samples were prepared by mixing blood samples of 2 porcine species in equal amounts[1][2]. 100 μl blood from LW, LL, and QC samples were prepared. Then samples were mixed with 100 μl pre-cold water and 800 μl pre-cooled methanol/acetonitrile (1:1, v/v). The ultrasound on the ice bath was performed for 60 min, and then left to incubate at -20 °C for 1 h to precipitate out any protein. The supernatant was obtained after centrifuging the tubes at 16000 x g for 20 min (at 4 °C). The remaining substance was dried in a high-speed vacuum enrichment centrifuge. 100 μl acetonitrile-water solution (1:1, v/v) was added to the dried substance and centrifuged at 16000 x g for 15 min (at 4 °C). The supernatant was subject for mass spectrometry analysis.


Refs:

[1] Broadhurst D, Goodacre R, Reinke SN, Kuligowski J, Wilson ID, Lewis MR, Dunn WB. Guidelines and considerations for the use of system suitability and quality control samples in mass spectrometry assays applied in untargeted clinical metabolomic studies. Metabolomics. 2018;14(6):72. doi:10.1007/s11306-018-1367-3. PMID: 29805336; PMCID: PMC5960010.

[2] Evans AM, O'Donovan C, Playdon M, Beecher C, Beger RD, Bowden JA, Broadhurst D et al.; Metabolomics Quality Assurance, Quality Control Consortium (mQACC). Dissemination and analysis of the quality assurance (QA) and quality control (QC) practices of LC-MS based untargeted metabolomics practitioners. Metabolomics. 2020 Oct 12;16(10):113. doi:10.1007/s11306-020-01728-5. PMID:33044703.

protocols.name: Chromatography
protocols.description: 5 μl previously processed supernatant was injected into an Agilent 1290 Infinity LC Ultra-High Performance Liquid Chromatography (UHPLC) system coupled to a Triple-TOF 5600 mass spectrometer (AB SCIEX). The column temperature was set 25 °C, and the flow rate was 0.3 ml/min. Chromatographic mobile phase A: water and 25 mM ammonium acetate and 25 mM ammonia water; B: Acetonitrile. The chromatography gradient elution procedure and Acetonitrile strength (in percentage) were set as follow: at 0-0.5 min 95%; 0.5-7 min, it changes linearly from 95% to 65%; 7-9 min, changes linearly from 65% to 40%; 9-10 min, it was maintained at 40%; 10-11.1 min, changed linearly from 40% to 95%; 11.1-16 min, maintained at 95%.

protocols.name: Mass spectrometry
protocols.description: QC samples were inserted into the sample queue to monitor and evaluate the system's stability and the experimental data's reliability. Electrospray ionization (ESI) was used to detect the positive and negative ion modes. All samples were separated by UPLC and analyzed by Triple-TOF 5600 mass spectrometer (AB SCIEX). ESI Source condition was set as follows: Ion Source Gas1 (Gas1): 60 psi; Ion Source Gas2 (Gas2): 60 psi; Curtain Gas (CUR): 30 psi; Source temperature: 600 °C; Ion Sapary Voltage Floating (ISVF) ± 5500V (positive and negative modes); TOF MS scan m/z range: 60-1200 Da; product ion scan m/z range: 25-1200 Da; TOF MS scan accumulation time 0.15 s/spectra; product ion scan accumulation time 0.03 s/spectra; The secondary mass spectrum was obtained by Information Dependency Acquisition (IDA), and the high sensitivity mode was adopted. Declustering potential (DP): ±60 V (plus and minus modes); Collision Energy: 30 eV. IDA was set as Exclude isotopes within 4 Da; Candidate ions to monitor per cycle: 6.

protocols.name: Data transformation
protocols.description: The program XCMS in MSDIAL was used for peak alignment, retention time correction and peak area extraction. Accurate mass number matching (<25 ppm) and secondary spectral matching were used to identify metabolite structure.

protocols.name: Metabolite identification
protocols.description: Then Human Metabolome Database (HMDB) and Massbank Database were taken as a reference for metabolite alignment. Those Metabolites with more than 50% missing value were removed. Positive and negative ion peaks were integrated, and SIMCA-P 14.1 (Umetrics, Umea, Sweden) was used to recognize all ion peak’s patterns.
